column397: And Billy Bumblebee said to Old Man Hoppy-toad, "Now you must leave our neighborhood, for we do not permit anyone to bother anyone else in the Town of Tinythings."
column398: So Old Man Hoppy-toad had to pack up all his things in a red handkerchief and hustle out of town.
column399: And Billy Bumblebee buzzed right around his head as Old Man Hoppy-toad went down the path "Lickity split-Hoppity hop!"
column400: and never once looked behind him.
column401: Thumbkins and Mrs. Thumbkins went back home, and when Billy Bumblebee returned and told them he had made Old Man Hoppy-toad go 'way down to the river they knew they would never be troubled with him again.
column402: Mrs. Thumbkins said she had fried pancakes all day but she was not too tired to fry more.
column403: So she made a lot of pancakes, while Billy Bumblebee flew home and returned with a bucket of honey, and they had so many pancakes Mrs. Thumbkins asked Billy Bumblebee if he would fly around and invite all the neighbors in to help eat them.
column404: Tommy Grasshopper, Granpa Tobackyworm, and all the other friends of the Thumbkins came and ate the lovely pancakes, covered with the delicious honey.
column405: And, after eating as much as they could, everybody caught hold of hands and danced until late in the night, for the Katydid orchestra was there to furnish the music.
column406: [Illustration] [Illustration] THE OLD, ROUGH STONE AND THE GNARLED TREE A great rough stone lay beneath a gnarled old tree.
column407: Years ago a tiny squirrel had climbed upon the stone to nibble some nuts, but before he had finished he was startled away.
column409: thought the stone to himself as he saw a nut roll to the ground, "now that nut will take root and grow into a tree and I will have to lie here for ages beneath its branches.
column410: I wish the silly squirrel had gone some other place to eat the nuts!"
column411: When the little nut took root and sent its tiny shoots up in the air, the old, rough Stone said, "There!
column413: and he disliked the tree from that time on.
column414: The old, rough Stone watched the tiny green shoot grow and grow until it grew into an enormous tree.
column415: "Just see how he pushes me up in the air with his roots!"
column416: the old, rough Stone said to himself.
column417: When the gnarled tree was covered with leaves in the summer time, the old, rough Stone said, "Just see how he hides the blue sky from my view!"
column418: And in the winter time when the limbs of the tree were bare, the old, rough Stone said, "Just see how he lets the snow and the cold rain fall right on me!"
column419: One night during a heavy storm the old, rough Stone heard a crash, and in the morning he saw the gnarled tree lying upon the ground.
column420: "Now I shall be all by myself again!"
column422: Then he counted the rings in the trunk of the gnarled tree until he came to three hundred, which was as far as he could count.
column423: "More than three hundred years have passed since that silly little squirrel dropped the nut from which this tree grew!"
column424: said the old, rough Stone to himself.
column425: [Illustration] Then men came with axes and cut up the tree and carried all of it away.
column426: When the hot summer days came the sun beat down upon the old, rough Stone and he missed the shade of the gnarled tree.
column429: said the old, rough Stone, "I wish the gnarled tree with its pretty rustling leaves were here again to shade me and keep me cool!"
column430: When winter came the old, rough Stone missed the leaves which fell around him and kept him warm.
column433: he cried, "I wish the gnarled tree would come back and scatter his leaves about me to protect me from the cold!"
column434: So years and years and years passed, and the great old, rough Stone lay all alone.
column435: "I wish another squirrel would come to eat nuts upon me!"
column437: "Squirrels are such knowing little creatures, I am sure another might drop a nut which would grow into a lovely tree to keep me company."
column438: But, many more years passed, and never again did a tiny squirrel sit upon the old, rough Stone and eat nuts.
column439: And never again did another tree grow above the old, rough Stone to keep him company.
column441: sighed the old, rough Stone, "We never know how well off we are until we lose something we really need!"
column442: [Illustration] SALLY MIGRUNDY Sally Migrundy lived all alone in a tiny little cottage no larger than a piano box.
column443: This was plenty large enough for Sally Migrundy though, for she was a tiny little lady herself.
column444: Sally Migrundy's tiny little cottage stood at the edge of a stream, a beautiful crystal clear stream of tinkling water which sang in a continual murmur all day and all night to Sally Migrundy.
column445: The stream tinkled merrily through a great forest which lay for miles and miles, a green mantle over the hills and valleys, and Sally Migrundy's tiny little cottage stood in the exact center of the great whispering forest.
column446: All the wood creatures knew and loved Sally Migrundy and she knew and loved all of the wood creatures.
column447: Each morning she would scatter food upon the surface of the singing stream and the lovely fish, their sides reflecting rainbow colors, would leap from the tinkling waters and splash about to show their pleasure.
column448: And she would place food about her little garden for the birds and they in turn repaid her by their wonderful melodies.
column449: Even the mama deer brought their little, wabbly-legged baby deer to introduce to Sally Migrundy; and she rubbed their sleek sides and talked to them so they couldn't but love her.
column450: Now Sally Migrundy had always lived in her tiny cottage on the bank of the tinkling stream which ran through the whispering forest.
column451: She had lived there when the largest trees in the forest were tiny little sprouts.
column452: She had lived there long before that, and even still longer than that, and that, and that.
column454: [Illustration] One day a man who lived on a hill many, many miles away from the whispering forest said to his wife: "Mother, wouldn't you like to know where the water that flows from our spring goes to?"
column455: And his wife replied: "It must travel until it reaches the ocean!"
column456: "Yes, I know that, mother" he replied, "but I mean, wouldn't it be interesting to know all of the country through which the water flows?"
column457: So the more they talked of it, the more interested they became until the man finally wrote upon a slip of paper and put the paper into a tiny bottle.
column458: Then he put the bottle upon the surface of the spring water and watched it float away.
column459: The little bottle floated along, tumbling over the tiny falls and tinkling ripples and bobbing up and down in the deep, blue, quiet, places until finally it floated to Sally Migrundy's and came to rest in the mass of pretty flowers where Sally Migrundy came each morning to dip her tiny bucket of water.
column460: And so Sally Migrundy found the tiny bottle and took it into her tiny house to read the tiny note she saw inside.
column461: It was such a nice, happy-hearted note Sally Migrundy said: "I will answer it!"
column462: So she wrote a happy-hearted note and asked whoever read it to come and visit her.
column463: Then she put her note in the tiny bottle and sent it dancing and bobbing down through the whispering forest, riding upon the surface of the singing stream.
column464: And Sally Migrundy's note floated along in the bottle until a little boy and a little girl saw it and picked it up.
column465: And when they read Sally Migrundy's happy-hearted note asking them to visit her they started following up the stream until after a long, long time they came to the tiny little cottage.
column466: Sally Migrundy was very much surprised to see the two children, for she had almost forgotten she had written the invitation.
column468: said Sally Migrundy, "Where in the world did you children come from?"
column469: "We found a note in a bottle and traveled up the stream until we came to your little cottage," they answered.
column470: [Illustration] "But won't your mamas and daddies be worried because you have been away from home so long?"
column473: Then Sally Migrundy kissed them and asked them into her tiny cottage.
column474: The door was so small the children had to get down upon their hands and knees to crawl through.
column475: But when they got inside they were surprised to find that the rooms were very large.
column476: In fact, Sally Migrundy's living room was larger inside than the whole little cottage was on the outside, for, as you have probably guessed, Sally Migrundy's cottage was a magic house.
column477: And in one corner of the living room there was a queer stand with a silver stem sticking up through the center, and the stem curved over and down towards five or six little crystal glasses.
column478: It was a magic soda fountain, as the children soon found out, and they could have all the soda water they wished at any time.
column479: In another room were two little snow white beds.
column480: These belonged to them, Sally Migrundy told the children.
column481: As you have probably guessed, the magic cottage took care to make everything comfortable for those who came inside.
column482: And when Sally Migrundy had shown the children their pretty bed room she took them to the dining room and there they found a table which had everything nice to eat upon it.
column483: And so the children ate and ate and ate, for the magic table knew just what the person wished for who sat at it.
column484: So you may be sure there were plenty of cookies and ice cream and candies and golden doughnuts and everything.
column485: So the two little orphan children lived all the time with Sally Migrundy.
column486: And each morning when they tumbled, laughing and shouting, out of their little snow white beds, they found underneath a new present.
column487: So each morning they had a new toy to play with, for the magic beds knew just what a child would like most each day.
column488: Sally Migrundy was very, very glad the children had come to live with her, so she wrote more notes and sent them down the singing stream, and more and more children came until Sally Migrundy's house was very, very large inside, but still the same tiny little cottage on the outside.
column489: The singing and happy laughter of the children echoed through the whispering forest all day, and the ground about the cottage was filled with toys and playthings,--merry-go-rounds, sliding boards, sand piles, hundreds of sand toys, and play houses filled with beautiful dolls and doll furniture.
column490: There was a roller coaster which knew just when to stop and start so that none of the children could ever hurt themselves upon it, and a little play grocery, a little play candy store, and a little play ice cream parlor so that the children could go there at any time and get cookies and candy and ice cream whenever they wished.
column491: You may be sure it was a very happy place to live and the children made Sally Migrundy very happy.
column492: At first the creatures who lived in the whispering forest were surprised to hear the happy laughter and to see so many children playing about, but they soon grew accustomed to the children and came right up to the grocery and candy store and ice cream parlor to be fed.
column493: Each year Sally Migrundy sends happy-hearted invitations floating down the stream and more orphan children come to live with her.
column494: However Sally Migrundy's tiny cottage is just the same tiny cottage on the outside.
column495: But when once you crawl through the tiny door, you look upon rows and rows of little rooms, each having one or more little snow white beds in it.
column496: [Illustration] And, while Sally Migrundy remains a tiny little lady only two feet high, she has as much happiness inside as if she were as large as a great big mountain, for as you have probably also guessed, she is a fairy and can have as much room inside for happiness as the little magic cottage could have room inside for all the happy children.
column497: One day the man who lived upon the hill where the spring bubbles up from the ground and makes the beginning of the singing stream said to his wife: "Mother, I will follow the stream and see where it leads to!"
column498: So he started down the stream and walked and walked and walked until the stream took him down through the whispering forest clear down to the sea.
column499: Then he turned around and walked back up the stream from the ocean--up through the whispering forest until he came again to his home at the top of the hill.
column500: "I followed the stream down through a great whispering forest, mother," he said, "until I came to the sea.
column501: Then I turned around and came back the same way.
column502: It was a beautiful trip and when I came to the center of the great whispering forest there was a clearing at the side of the tinkling, singing stream, and the lovely fish leaped from the crystal waters and showed me their wonderful coloring, and the clearing was filled with beautiful flowers and the music of birds.
column503: And it was so beautiful I stopped and watched and listened.
column504: "It seemed as if hundreds of children were playing around me, and although I could not hear them yet it seemed to me that I felt they were shouting and laughing at their play!"
column508: And when I returned I again stopped at the same place and sat and listened to the singing of the waters and the birds, and I saw the wild creatures come down into the clearing and act as if they were being fed, and all the time I seemed to feel the laughter and happy shouting of children at play.
column509: And a most delightful feeling of contentment and happiness came over me as if I sat within the borders of Fairyland!
column510: "Then as I stooped to drink of the tinkling waters before I started on my way home, I saw, tied to a flower growing in the water, the tiny little bottle with the note inside which I had floated off a long time ago, so I brought it home with me!"
column511: And from his knapsack the man took the tiny bottle and placed it on the table before his wife.
column512: "I wish we knew just who tied the bottle to the flower!"
column513: said the wife as she picked the bottle up to look at it.
column514: And because the bottle had been used by Sally Migrundy, the two good people suddenly knew all about Sally Migrundy, the magic little cottage, and the happy children who lived there.
column515: Every year the man takes his wife, and together they walk down the tinkling stream until they came to the exact center of the great whispering forest; there they sit for hours at a time, feeling the happiness that overflows from the hearts of Sally Migrundy and the children.
column516: And while the good couple have not been able to see the children or Sally Migrundy, or even the tiny magic cottage, they know they are all there, for at times they can hear the laughter and once in a while they feel the touch of a tiny hand.
column517: And when they return to their home upon the hill they find they have received enough happiness at the clearing beside the tinkling, singing water to last them for a whole year.
column518: [Illustration] [Illustration] HOW JOHNNY CRICKET SAW SANTA CLAUS When the first frost came and coated the leaves with its film of sparkles, Mamma Cricket, Papa Cricket, Johnny Cricket and Grandpa Cricket decided it was time they moved into their winter home.
column519: Papa and Mamma and Grandpa Cricket carried all the heavy Cricket furniture, while Johnny Cricket carried the lighter things, such as the family portraits, looking glasses, knives and forks and spoons, and his own little violin.
column520: Aunt Katy Didd wheeled Johnny's little sister Teeny in the Cricket baby buggy and helped Mamma Cricket lay the rugs and wash the stone-work, for you see the Cricket winter home was in the chimney of a big old-fashioned house and the walls were very dusty, and everything was topsy-turvy.
column521: But Mamma Cricket and Aunt Katy Didd soon had everything in tip-top order, and the winter home was just as clean and neat as the summer home out under the rose bush had been.
column522: There the Cricket family lived happily and every thing was just as cozy as any little bug would care to have; on cold nights the people who owned the great big old fashioned house always made a fire in the fireplace, so the walls of the Cricket's winter home were nice and warm, and little Teeny Cricket could play on the floor in her bare feet without fear of catching cold and getting the Cricket croup.
column523: There was one crack in the walls of the Crickets' winter home which opened right into the fireplace, so the light from the fire always lit up the Crickets' living room.
column524: Papa Cricket could read the Bugville News while Johnny Cricket fiddled all the latest popular Bug Songs and Mamma Cricket rocked and sang to little Teeny Cricket.
column525: One night, though, the people who owned the great big old fashioned house did not have a fire in the fireplace, and little Teeny Cricket was bundled up in warm covers and rocked to sleep, and all the Cricket family went to bed in the dark.
column526: Johnny Cricket had just dozed into dreamland when he was awakened by something pounding ... ever so loudly ... and he slipped out of bed and into his two little red topped boots and felt his way to the crack in the living room wall.
column527: Johnny heard loud voices and merry peals of laughter, so he crawled through the crack and looked out into the fireplace.
column528: There in front of the fireplace he saw four pink feet and two laughing faces way above, while just a couple of Cricket-hops from Johnny's nose was a great big man.
column529: Johnny could not see what the man was pounding, but he made an awful loud noise.
column530: Finally the pounding ceased and the man leaned over and kissed the owners of the pink feet.
column531: Then there were a few more squeals of laughter, and the four pink feet pitter-patted across the floor and Johnny could see the owners hop into a snow-white bed.
column532: Then Johnny saw the man walk to the lamp and turn the light down low, and leave the great big room.
column533: Johnny Cricket jumped out of the crack into the fireplace and ran out into the great big room so that he might see what the man had pounded.
column534: The light from the lamp was too dim for him to make out the objects hanging from the mantel above the fireplace.
column535: All he could see were four long black things, so Johnny Cricket climbed up the bricks at the side of the fireplace until he came to the mantel shelf, then he ran along the shelf and looked over.
column537: Johnny began to wish that he had stopped to put on his stockings, for he was in his bare feet.
column538: He had removed his little red topped boots when he decided to climb up the side of the fireplace and now his feet were cold.
column539: So Johnny started to climb over the mantel shelf and down the side of the fireplace when there came a puff of wind down the chimney which made the stockings swing away out into the room, and snowflakes fluttered clear across the room.
column540: There was a tiny tinkle from a bell and, just as Johnny hopped behind the clock, he saw a boot stick out of the fireplace.
column541: Then Johnny Cricket's little bug heart went pitty-pat, and sounded as if it would run a race with the ticking of the clock.
column542: From his hiding place, Johnny Cricket heard one or two chuckles, and something rattle.
column543: Johnny crept along the edge of the clock and holding the two feelers over his back looked from his hiding place.... At first all he could see were two hands filling the stockings with rattly things, but when the hands went down below the mantel for more rattly things, Johnny Cricket saw a big round smiling face all fringed with snow-white whiskers.
column544: Johnny drew back into the shadow of the clock, and stayed there until the rattling had ceased and all had grown quiet, then he slipped from behind the clock and climbed down the side of the fireplace as fast as he could.
column545: Johnny Cricket was too cold to stop and put on his little red boots, but scrambled through the crack in the fireplace and hopped into bed.
column546: In the morning Mamma Cricket had a hard time getting Johnny Cricket out of bed.
column547: He yawned and stretched, put on one stocking, rubbed his eyes, yawned, put on another stocking and yawned again.
column548: Johnny was still very sleepy and could hardly keep his eyes open as he reached for his little red-topped boots.
column549: Johnny's toe struck something hard, he yawned, rubbed his eyes and looked into the boot.
column550: Yes, there was something in Johnny Cricket's boot!
column551: He picked up the other boot; it, too, had something in it!
column553: With a loud cry for such a little Cricket, Johnny rushed to the kitchen and showed Mamma, then he told her of his adventure of the night before.
column554: Mamma Cricket called Papa and they both had a laugh when Johnny told how startled he had been at the old man with the white whiskers who filled the stockings in front of the fireplace.
column559: We have watched him every Christmas in the last four years fill the stockings, and he saw your little red topped boots and filled them with candy, too.
column560: If you will crawl through the crack into the fireplace you will see the children of the people who own this big house playing with all the presents that Santa Claus left them!"
column561: And, sure enough, it was so!
column562: [Illustration] [Illustration] THE TWIN SISTERS Everybody in the little village called them the twin houses because they were built exactly alike.
column563: But the two little cottages looked different even if they were built alike, for one was covered with climbing vines and beautiful scarlet roses while the other had no vines or flowers about it at all.
column564: Everybody called the two cottages the twin houses for another reason: the owners were twins.
column565: One of the twins was Matilda and the other Katrinka and they were as much alike on the outside as their two cottages were alike; but as their two cottages differed, so did the two twins differ.
column566: Matilda could not be told from Katrinka should you just see them walking down the street, but the minute either of them spoke you would know which was Matilda and which was Katrinka.
column567: Matilda, who lived in the bare cottage, was sour and disagreeable, while Katrinka was happy and cheery.
column568: So the people in the little village called Matilda "Matilda Grouch" and they called Katrinka "Katrinka Sunshine".
column569: All the children of the little village loved Katrinka, for she always had a cooky or a dainty in her apron pocket to give them, or she would pat them on their curly heads and smile cheerily at them through her glasses.
column570: And all the children avoided Matilda, for, sometimes mistaking her for Katrinka and running close to greet her, they would have their noses tweeked for their trouble.
column571: Matilda's life was lonely and cold; no one went to see her.
column573: [Illustration] Katrinka's house always echoed with the laughter of children; everyone went to see her.
column574: She was always joyful and cheery.
column575: One night while Matilda sat at her dark window looking across at Katrinka's house, she saw a crowd of people tip-toeing up to the stoop with baskets under their arms and flowers in their hands and when all had crowded upon the porch they stamped their feet and made a great noise.
column576: Matilda was very angry, but Katrinka ran laughing to the door and greeted all with her kindliest smile.
column577: It was a surprise party for Katrinka, for it was her birthday.
column578: Matilda watched the party from her dark window and the longer she watched, the more angry she grew, for the longer the party lasted, the louder grew the happy laughter.
column579: Finally when all the guests had gone, Matilda saw Katrinka gather up half of the presents and put them in a basket.
column580: Then Katrinka stole softly up to Matilda's stoop and stamped her feet.
column581: Matilda sat scowling by the dark window a long time before she finally went to the door, for she was very peevish.
column582: "This is a fine time to come stamping upon a person's stoop!"
column583: she scolded, as Katrinka walked into the living room.
column584: "Oh, sister," Katrinka cried, as she tried to kiss Matilda.
column585: "This is our birthday and I have brought you half of the presents which were given me!
column587: and she piled the presents high upon the table.
column589: said Matilda, frowning at her sister.
column590: But Katrinka could see that Matilda _did_ wish them.
column591: "The presents were not for me, Katrinka!"
column595: "They were given to me and I give them to you!
column596: I have saved one half for myself!
column597: But you should have been to the party!"
column598: said Katrinka, "We had such a happy time!"
column599: "I do not enjoy being with people!"
column600: Matilda scolded, "I wish to be left to myself!"
column601: "Yes, but Matilda," her sister said, "you do not know the happiness in being kind and friendly to others!"
column604: "I just wish you could take my place and know the happiness that is in my heart tonight," Katrinka smiled.
column605: "I just wish you could take my place and know the unhappiness that is in my heart tonight!"
column606: said Matilda, "You would see that a lot of children screeching about the house with all their presents could not bring me happiness!"
column607: Katrinka thought a moment, "I have it, Matilda!
column609: You must live in my house and pretend that you are me, and I will live in your house and pretend that I am you!
column610: And you must smile and be friendly just as I would do."
column611: After a great deal of coaxing, Matilda finally agreed that she would change places with Katrinka and try to smile when anyone came to see her.
column614: So Matilda went over to Katrinka's cottage and went to bed and Katrinka stayed in Matilda's cottage, but she did not go to bed.
column615: Instead she went all over the house and tidied everything up and placed pretty white curtains at the windows.
column616: In the morning neighbors came to Katrinka's house, and Matilda, taking Katrinka's place met them with a smile, and soon in spite of herself she was laughing and enjoying herself.
column617: And when they left, Matilda felt that she enjoyed having them there.
column618: But what was the callers' surprise when they passed Matilda's cottage to see someone planting flowers around the stoop.
column619: They stopped in wonderment and, as Katrinka looked up at them with a cheery "Good Morning!"
column620: and a happy smile they could scarce believe their eyes and ears, for they thought it was Matilda.
column621: And these callers told other neighbors and they called at Katrinka's house and visited with Matilda and Matilda was so pleased she laughed as cheerily as Katrinka could laugh.
column622: And as the neighbors left they saw Katrinka in Matilda's front yard planting flowers and stopped in open mouthed wonder to gaze at her, for _they_ thought she was Matilda.
column623: And when Katrinka smiled at them and said her cheery "Good morning" _they_ could scarcely believe their eyes and ears.
column624: The neighbors all put their heads together, and that evening they filled their baskets with goodies and presents and, with large bouquets of flowers, they tiptoed up to Matilda's front stoop and stamped their feet.
column625: Now Katrinka had called Matilda over to her own house to see the changes she had made and Matilda was beginning to see what she had missed all along.
column626: And as they were talking, there came a noise at the front stoop.
column627: "Shall I go to the door, Matilda?"
column630: Matilda replied, her face alight with happiness.
column631: So Matilda welcomed her guests as cheerily as Katrinka had done the evening before and the laughter lasted until 'way in the night.
column632: And when the last guest had left, Matilda took Katrinka in her arms and said, "I will not need to change places with you again, Katrinka, for I have found that there is far more pleasure in being happy than in being unhappy!"
column635: "You see, in order to be happy ourselves we must reflect happiness to others, and the more cheer we give to others the more joy we receive ourselves, so we must continue to change from one house to another every other day so that no one will know which of us is Matilda and which is Katrinka and we will share our happiness with each other."
column636: So Matilda's house was soon surrounded with beautiful flowers and her house echoed with the fun and laughter of happy children.
column637: And the two sisters who looked alike now acted alike and could not be told apart, and they changed about so often people never knew whether they were visiting Katrinka or whether they were visiting Matilda, for one was as cheery as the other and was as happy in the love of all the people in the little village.
column638: And, as they could not be told apart, everyone called Matilda or Katrinka the Cheery Twins whenever they spoke of either.
column639: [Illustration] [Illustration] LITTLE THUMBKIN'S GOOD DEED Thumbkins lived in a tiny, cozy little house right down beneath a mushroom.
column640: The tiny, little house was made of cobwebs which Thumbkins had gathered from the bushes and weeds.
column641: These he had woven together with thistle-down, making the nicest little nest imaginable.
column642: One day Thumbkins was passing through the meadow and it began to rain.
column645: Thumbkins cried as he hurried along.
column646: A mamma meadow-lark, sitting upon her nest, saw Thumbkins running and called to him: "Come here, little man, and get beneath my wing and I will keep you warm and dry!"
column647: So Thumbkins crawled beneath Mamma Meadow-Lark's wings and, snuggling down close to the bottom of the meadow-lark's nest, he found three tiny little baby meadow-larks.
column648: It was too dark for Thumbkins to see them, but he felt that the baby Meadow-Larks were as warm as toast.
column649: Thumbkins kept very quiet, for the baby meadow-larks were sleepy little fellows, and before he knew it Thumbkins was sound asleep himself, with an arm around one of the baby birds.
column650: [Illustration] Thumbkins did not know how long he had been asleep, but when he awakened the rain had ceased.
column651: Thumbkins knew it had stopped raining for he could no longer hear the rain drops pattering upon Mamma Meadow-Lark's back.
column652: So now he climbed out of the nest and looked about.
column653: The ground about the Meadow-Lark's nest was covered with tiny puddles, and Mamma Meadow-Lark was soaking wet.
column655: Her feathers stuck out in all directions and a drop of water fell from her head and rolled down her beak.
column656: Thumbkins thought at first Mamma Meadow-Lark was crying, and he said: "Are you cold, Mamma Meadow-Lark?"
column658: Mamma Meadow-Lark replied as she shook her ruffled feathers, sending the water flying in all directions.
column659: "But, you see," she continued, "if I did not cover my baby Meadow-Lark chicks they would get very, very cold, for they have little bald heads with not a single feather upon them to protect them!
column660: So, while I get wet, it does not matter so much, for I know I have kept my little Meadow-Lark chicks dry and warm and cozy and that, of course, makes me very happy!
column661: And I had the pleasure of keeping you warm and dry, too!"
column663: "Perhaps Mamma Meadow-Lark is very happy inside!"
column664: Thumbkins thought to himself as he stood and looked at her.
column665: "But she does not look very happy with such wet feathers."
column666: "I thank you ever and ever so much, Mamma Meadow-Lark!"
column668: "You are indeed very welcome," Mamma Meadow-Lark replied, "and any time it rains you can come back to my nest and crawl beneath my wing and keep warm and dry.
column669: For you are tiny and do not take up much room!"
column670: Thumbkins thanked Mamma Meadow-Lark again, and told her of his nice warm cozy little nest beneath the mushroom.
column671: "It is always nice and dry there," he said, "for the rain runs right off the mushroom and does not touch my little cobweb home!"
column672: That night as he lay in his little thistle-down bed, Thumbkins heard it thundering.
column673: "I'm very glad that I haven't a home built right out upon the bare ground like the meadow-larks!"
column675: And as the thunder grew louder, Thumbkins turned over and tried to go to sleep.
column676: Presently the raindrops began to patter on the round top of the mushroom and "drip-dropped" to the ground without getting Thumbkins' little house the least bit wet.
column677: Usually when it rained, the patter of the raindrops upon his mushroom roof lulled Thumbkins right to sleep, but tonight Thumbkins lay wide awake and thought and thought.
column679: Thumbkins said, so he hopped out of his warm little bed and lit his tiny lantern.
column680: Then, though it was raining ever so hard, he pulled his little hat well down on his head and ran out into the storm.
column682: There was Mamma Meadow-Lark sitting upon her nest with her head tucked under her wing, sound asleep.
column683: But when he held his tiny lantern close, Thumbkins could see that she shivered as the cold raindrops splashed upon her back.
column684: So Thumbkins ran to the woods where he knew the mushrooms grew, and breaking off the largest one he could find he carried it to where Mamma Meadow-Lark sat sleeping upon her nest, and planted it so the raindrops rolled off the round roof and did not touch her at all.
column685: Then, shivering himself, for he was soaking wet, he ran home as fast as he could, took off his dripping clothes, put on his little pajamas, and climbed into his warm little cozy cobweb bed.
column686: Now of course Thumbkins was happy because he had helped another, and when a person is happy there is nothing to worry about, and when there is nothing to worry about, of course there is nothing to keep one awake.
column687: So Thumbkins fell fast asleep and dreamed the most pleasant dreams.
column688: And they were such happy dreams Thumbkins slept until almost half-past eight the next morning.
